content.p: Preganglionic neurons in the parasympathetic nervous system arise from two distinct origins: Brainstem cell groups or cells in the lateral horn of the spinal cord. Select one of these origins as the best choice.

response.feedback: Correct. Postganglionic neurons to the submandibular, sublingual, and parotid glands receive input from the Edinger-Westphal cell group in the brainstem, causing salivation.
Incorrect. In the parasympathetic nervous system, lateral horn cells in the spinal cord innervate muscles, glands, and tissues at and below large intestine level.

part.hint: Muscles, glands, and tissues of the torso and abdomen superior to the small intestines are served by preganglionic neurons from brainstem cell groups.

response.feedback: Correct. Postganglionic neurons to the ciliary muscle of the pupil receive input from the Edinger-Westphal cell group in the brainstem, causing pupillary constriction.
Incorrect. In the parasympathetic nervous system, lateral horn cells in the spinal cord innervate muscles, glands, and tissues at and below large intestine level.

part.hint: Muscles, glands, and tissues of the torso and abdomen superior to the small intestines are served by preganglionic neurons from brainstem cell groups.

response.feedback: Incorrect. In the parasympathetic nervous system, preganglionic neurons from brainstem cell groups synapse onto postganglionic neurons that innervate smooth muscle, tissues, and glands at the intestine level and higher.
Correct. Preganglionic neurons from the lateral horn at sacral levels S2-S4 synapse onto postganglionics that innervate the uterus.
